Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Situation2: They strictly follow a detailed schedule of daily prayers, chanting, and offerings, ensuring nothing is skipped.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to start my evening prayers. It was Priya, my closest friend, texting, “Had the worst day. Can I call you?” I knew she needed me—she always said I was the only one who really listened. As a friend, I wanted to be there for her, to let her vent and feel heard. But as a practicing Hindu, I had a strict schedule for my evening rituals. The incense was already lit, the lamp flickering, and the mantras waiting on my lips. Missing even a part of my daily prayers left me feeling unsettled, as if I’d let something sacred slip away. I stared at my phone, torn. If I answered Priya, I’d have to rush or skip my prayers, betraying my spiritual discipline. If I ignored her, I’d be letting down someone who counted on me. My thumb hovered over the screen, heart pounding, caught between the pull of friendship and the call of faith.
